Name: Is there a distinct category of dual for verbal agreement with a dual subject?
Comment: Finite verbs agree in number and person with the subject.

Name: Is non-agreement in number between the nominal subject and verbal predicate possible?
Can finite verbs agree in number with a nominal object?
Comment: The verb not only indicates that the object is determinate but also encodes the number of the object (SG, PL, DU).

Name: Can an adnominal property word agree with the noun in case?
Comment: Attributive adjectives are not inflected for case or number.

Name: Is there non-agreement between an adnominal property word and the head noun?
Comment: Attributive adjectives are not inflected for case or number.

Name: Can adpositions be used to mark core verbal arguments?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (S/A) marking?
Can non-finite clauses use a special means for core argument (P) marking?
Do the characteristics of the object referent (topicality, animacy, definiteness) influence object marking?
Does object marking correlate with aspectuality?
Does object marking depend on the verb conjugation form?
Is there differential subject marking?
Can S and A be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Can S and P be conflated morphologically across clause boundaries, i.e., act as a syntactic pivot?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Is there grammatical marking of habituality?
Comment: See also UT017.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of frequentativity?
Comment: See also UT016.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of progressivity?
Is it common to use a verb in the present tense for future time reference?
Comment: There is no separate future tense in Mansi, the present tense may also get future interpretation in a proper context.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the immediate future?
Comment: The respective meaning is usually conveyed by the verb in the present tense form + context.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of the pluperfect?
Can aspect be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Can tense be expressed overtly in the negative marker?
Comment: Tense is marked on the lexical verb.

Name: Is there grammatical marking of mirativity?
Comment: In Northern Mansi, mirative forms have evolved through desubordination, thus, there is reason to regard mirativity as a separate category. The category of evidentiality and, accordingly mirativity, has different origins in Khanty dialects.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of a desire or wish?
Comment: For the 1st person the particle wos ~ os with indicative present may be used. However, -nuw, conventionally labelled as a conditional marker, is also used as an optative marker, e.g., jomas jurt wēk χōnt-nuw-əm [good friend only find-COND-1SG] 'If only I found a good friend / I would want to find a good friend'.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to irrealis?
Are verbs marked with a non-indicative mood in counterfactual conditional clauses?
Comment: The 'if'-clause does not contain conditional marker (see Riese 2001:48), e.g., at ke jursʲ-al-as-lən manar-e al-nuw-uw [NEG if team_up-MOM-PST-SG<2SG what-SG<3SG kill-COND-1PL] ’If you wouldn't have taken me as a companion, what would have we hunted?’ (OUBD 1235:231).

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic necessity?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of epistemic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of deontic possibility?
Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 3Sg?
Comment: The volitional particle wos(s) 'let' + indicative non-past form can be used.

Name: Is there morphological marking on the verb used to direct commands/wishes, etc. to the 1Sg?
Comment: The volitional particle wos(s) 'let' + indicative non-past form can be used.

Name: Is it common to use the imperative/jussive in complement clauses introduced by predicates expressing wish/desire/will?
Is there morphological marking on the verb dedicated to the expression of apprehension?
Is there a reflexive conjugation?
Can non-singular 2nd and 3rd person have the same person/number marking or morphosyntactic treatment?
Comment: There is syncretism between 2SG ~ 2DU ~ 2PL possessive suffixes, e.g., śōpit-as-aγən repair-PST-DU<2SG ~ repair-PST-DU<2DU ~ repair-PST-DU<2PL.

Name: Can the 3rd person plural verb form and impersonal (passive) verb form be encoded in the same way?
Are 2nd person singular verb forms commonly used with a generic meaning?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Can an infinitival verb form be used in a directive function?
Can verbs in purposive subordinate clauses be bare infinitive forms?
Are there sentences without overt verbal arguments?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the 3rd person singular forms of the present tense?
Is a copula commonly used for predicate nominals in the past tense?
Can locative constructions commonly occur without a copula?
Is the same coordinating conjunction commonly used for NPs, VPs, and clauses?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: There are no original coordination conjunctions in Mansi; NPs have their own coordinating strategies (e.g., dual or plural forms or the particle os 'also'); VPs and clauses are connected through juxtaposition or bridging linkage (based on non-finite clause combining). Recently the Russian i 'and' is borrowed - and the functions of os 'also' are extended to clauses.

Name: Does existential negation have a special negator?
Comment: There is a separate element for existential negation – āt'im.

Name: Can standard negation be asymmetric in the present tense?
Comment: Negation is symmetric.

Name: Can non-finite dependent clauses use the standard negation construction?
Is there a special negator that combines with non-finite forms?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Are there special negative non-finite forms?
Comment: The suffix -tāl ~ -tal is used to make privative adjectives from nouns and privative participles from verbs.

Name: Is there an impersonal passive construction?
Comment: Intransitive verbs, including meteorological, can take passive voice marking.

Name: Are there non-finite forms specializing in the relativization of particular core participants, e.g., subjects (S/A), direct objects (P), absolutive participants (S/P)?
Comment: The past and present participles are not specialized, but there is a past passive participle relativizing direct objects/patient only.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize all core participants (S/A/P) and possibly also some non-core participants?
Comment: The past and present participles can relativize all core and some non-core participants.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can relativize at least some non-core participants but cannot relativize all core participants?
Is there a specialized negative participial form, which cannot be analyzed as a specific participial marker + negative marker?
Comment: The suffix -tāl ~ -tal is not transparent from a syncronous perspective.

Name: Is there a future participle?
Comment: However, the present participle is actually a non-past participle, referring both to the present and the future.

Name: Are there participles that can encode their subject with possessive suffixes?
Are there participles that must agree with the nouns they modify in case and number in all contexts?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and action nominalizations?
Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and agentive nominalizations?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: Agentive nominalizations use lexical nominalizers like xum 'person' with a participle.

Name: Are there non-finite forms that can be used both as participles and converbs?
Is OV the neutral order in affirmative imperative clauses?
Comment: Same word order as in declarative clauses - OV - unless it appears in emphatic construction, esp. in newer Russian-influenced texts (due to the focus position in Russian being in the sentence-final position).

Name: Is it possible to place an object between the negative marker and the main verb in imperative constructions?
Is there diminutive (hypocoristic) marking on verbs?
Can modifiers of action nominalizations in agent and patient roles both be encoded like possessors?
Comment: As there is no genitive in Mansi, the nominative is used (i.e. zero marking) for both  possessors and subjects of non-finite forms; but personal marking is with possessive suffixes.

Name: Can the modifier of action nominalizations in the patient role be encoded like a direct object?
Comment: The nominative is the only option for nouns; for pronouns there are oblique forms (traditionally called accusative, though the classification is problematic).

Name: Do core adjectives agree with the subject noun in number in the predicative position?
Is there a bound superlative degree marker on property words?
Can adpositions have person/number marking?
Are there adpositions that show a tripartite system?
Comment: There are, however, also adpositions which do not make such a distinction.

Name: Is there case compounding?
Are there morphological cases only used with pronouns?
Comment: Oblique forms (traditionally called accusative, though the classification is problematic), e.g., ānəm 'me', tawe 'him/her'; originally they are pronouns with possessive  markers of the same person; they can take other case  markers, e.g., ānəm-nəl (1SG.OBL-ABL) 'from me'.

Name: Does the numeral modification of a noun have an effect on its case selection?
Comment: The nominative case is used.

Name: Is the singular form of the noun also used with numerals greater than 1?
Comment: The numeral kit 'two' can be followed by singular or dual. Plural is not used with numerals.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses indirect object/recipient/goal (different from a local case)?
Comment: See UT086.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses a terminative meaning?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the absence of a referent (abessive)?
Comment:
However, there is a suffix -tal ~ -tāl traditionally classified as a privative derivational suffix (when used denominally) and the negative participle when used deverbally. But!
Denominal forms can also be used as indirect objects, e.g. neː-taːl χos oːl-əs (woman-PRIV long live-PST.3SG)
'(he) lived without a wife for a long time' (OUDB > northern mansi > 1239: 4). Thus one could in theory call this a case suffix too.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses motion along or by a referent (prolative)?
Is there a locative case that expresses goal?
Comment: The dative (traditionally called lative) has two basic functions: 1) indirect object, 2) goal of a movement.

Name: Is there a locative case that expresses location?
Is there a locative case that expresses source?
Is there case syncretism for goal and location marking?
Is there case syncretism for location and source marking?
Are there two sets of local cases?
Are there three or more sets of local cases?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental) and/or accompaniment (comitative)?
Comment: Additionally there is a comitative postposition used both with animate nouns and personal pronouns.

Name: Is there a case that expresses the means by which something is carried out (instrumental), which is different from a case that expresses accompaniment (comitative) or other relations?
Comment: A postpositional construction is used.

Name: Is there a dedicated case that expresses the result of a change of state (translative) and/or a state of being (essive)?
Comment: The respective case (called the translative) has both functions.

Name: Is there a case that expresses a state of being (essive), which is different from a case that expresses the result of a change of state (translative) or other relations?
Is there a dedicated case that expresses equativity?
Is there an inflectional nominal marker for expressing benefactive or destinative semantics independent from the dative?
Is there (in addition to the basic declension) a declension different from a possessive declension?
Is it possible to use the singular with the paired body parts/clothing/accessories that accompany them?
Comment: Cf. sam-pal 'one eye' (lit. half an eye). With possessive marking the dual appears: sam-aγ-e 'his (two) eyes'.

Name: Can the marking of the possessor in the attributive construction vary?
Comment: The possessor is always unmarked.

Name: Can the possessor in the attributive construction be encoded with the nominative?
Are singular and plural possessee distinguished in the possessive declension?
Comment: There are different suffixes for  singular, dual and plural.

Name: Can a 2Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Can a 3Sg possessive suffix be used to mark definiteness?
Comment: Whether the possessive suffix indicates possession or definiteness, becomes clear from the context.

Name: Is there a human vs. non-human distinction in independent interrogative pronouns?
Comment: The distinction is humans vs. non-humans, xoːŋxɑ/χotjut 'who' is used with people and manər 'what' with animals or inanimate objects.

Name: Does 'who' commonly appear as a relative pronoun used for animates other than humans?
Comment: There are no relative pronouns, only in very modern texts as obvious Russian influence.

Name: Does 'who' commonly appear as a relative pronoun used for inanimates?
Comment: There are no relative pronouns, only in very modern texts as obvious Russian influence.

Name: Can a demonstrative stem be used as a pronoun with a 3Sg human referent?
Source: Bakró-Nagy et al. 2022:in passim; Riese 2001:in passim

Name: Are there possessive suffixes, the position of which varies in relation to case/number suffixes?
Comment: The order is stem + possessive suffix + case suffix.

Name: Are case and number marked cumulatively across the paradigm?
Are there different words for mother’s brother and father’s brother?
Are there different words for younger and older relatives for relations other than siblings?
Is there an animacy distinction for both concepts: 'new/young' and 'old'?
Is there a distinction for both 'warm' and 'cold' depending on whether reference is to weather or the temperature of objects?
Source: Jeremy Bradley, Csilla Horváth, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Is there contrastive length for consonants?
Comment: No length opposition in the consonant system.

Name: Is there contrastive length for vowels?
Is there a contrast between short and long unstressed vowels?
Comment: The primary stress is on the first syllable; vowels in non-first syllables are short.

Name: Is there a contrast in the length of geminate consonants?
Comment: No phonemic value.

Name: Are there more than two phonological quantities?
Are there extralong syllables?
Is the main foot structure trochaic?
Comment: Mansi has consistent first syllable stress.

Name: Is there lexically distinctive word stress?
Is there morphologically conditioned stress?
Is there fixed primary stress?
Is there stress in heavy syllables?
Comment: Stress depends on the position and not on the weight of the syllable.

Name: Is there non-initial primary stress?
Is there palatal vowel harmony?
Is there velar vowel harmony?
Is there labial vowel harmony?
Are there closing diphthongs?
Are there opening diphthongs?
Is there a qualitative contrast between subsets of short and long vowels?
Are there full vs. reduced vowels as contrastive subsets?
Comment: On phonological level there are no reduced vs. full contrastive subsets. In non-first syllables there is a middle, central [ǝ] but this is not a reduced vowel.

Name: Is there a high front rounded vowel /y/?
Is there a mid-high front rounded vowel /ø/?
Is there a high back unrounded vowel /ɯ ɨ/?
Comment: Only as a phonetic variant of /i/.

Name: Is there a mid-high back unrounded vowel /ɤ ɘ/?
Is there a low back rounded vowel /ɒ/?
Is there a contrast between mid front vowels (/e/ or /ɛ/) and low front vowels (/æ/ or /a/)?
Source: Marianne Bakró-Nagy, Csilla Horváth, Jeremy Bradley, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)

Name: Are there word-initial consonant clusters?
Comment: Present in Russian loanwords.

Name: Are there word-internal consonant clusters in the syllable onset?
Comment: In three-constituent consonant clusters, the first constituent is the coda of the previous, the second and third consonants are the onset of the next syllable, cf. Coda-maximalization.

Name: Are there consonant clusters in the syllable coda?
Comment: Only in monosyllabic words and in word-final syllables.

Name: Are there word-internal intervocalic clusters of three or more consonants?
Comment: Three (or more) constituent clusters in stems are sporadic; they occur mostly in derivations or other affixed forms on morpheme boundaries. (In most cases a non-phonemic epenthetic schwa appears before the third or fourth constituent of non-homorganic clusters: njeːlǝm ‘tongue’ ⟶ njeːlm-ǝt tongue-PL, joxt-ǝs come-PST(.3SG) ⟶ joxt-sǝm come-PST.1SG.)

Name: Are there word-final clusters of three or more consonants?
Are there palatalized alveolar consonants?
Source: Marianne Bakró-Nagy, Jeremy Bradley, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: There are no palatalized, but alveo-palatal consonants.

Name: Are there palatalized labial and velar consonants?
Source: Marianne Bakró-Nagy, Csilla Horváth, Jeremy Bradley, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: No palatalized, but alveo-palatal consonants.

Name: Is there a palatal stop?
Comment: Present in Russian loanwords.

Name: Is there a palatal nasal /ɲ/?
Source: Marianne Bakró-Nagy, Csilla Horváth, Jeremy Bradley, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: More precisely an alveo-palatal consonant.

Name: Is there a palatal lateral /ʎ/?
Source: Marianne Bakró-Nagy, Csilla Horváth, Jeremy Bradley, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: More precisely an alveo-palatal consonant.

Name: Is there a velar nasal /ŋ/?
Comment: However, it does not occur in a word initial position.

Name: Is there an alveolar affricate /t͡s/?
Comment: There are no affricates in North Mansi.

Name: Is there a non-alveolar affricate (e.g., /t͡ʃ/, /t͡ɕ/)?
Comment: There are no affricates in North Mansi.

Name: Is there a phonological contrast between an unvoiced alveolar sibilant /s/ and an unvoiced postalveolar sibilant /ʃ/?
Source: Marianne Bakró-Nagy, Csilla Horváth, Jeremy Bradley, and Elena Skribnik (p.c. 2020)
Comment: Present in Russian loanwords.

Name: Are there voiced plosives (e.g., /b g d/)?
Comment: Present in Russian loanwords.

Name: Is there a glottal stop /ʔ/?
Is there a phonological contrast between plain and labial velar consonants (e.g., /k/ vs. /kʷ/)?
Comment: There is contrast between /k/ vs. /kʷ/, /χ/ vs. /χʷ/.

Name: Is there a constraint on the word-initial alveolar trill /r/?
Is there a laryngeal fricative /h/?
Is there a voiced velar fricative /ɣ/?
Comment: However, it does not occur in a word initial position.

Name: Is there a voiceless velar fricative /x/?
Is there a voiced dental fricative /ð/?
Is there a labio-velar approximant /w/?
Is there a voiceless labiodental fricative /f/?
Comment: Present in Russian loanwords.

Name: Is there radical qualitative consonant gradation?
Comment: No gradations but paradigmatic alternations.

Name: Is there quantitative consonant gradation?
Comment: No gradations but paradigmatic alternations.
